item.title: Upgrading Quartz
item.description: Note This is specifically a guide for upgrading Quartz 4 version to a more recent update. If you are coming from Quartz 3, check out the migration guide for more info.

item.title: Components
item.description: Want to create your own custom component? Check out the advanced guide on creating components for more information.

item.title: Quartz Showcase
item.description: Want to see what Quartz can do? Here are some cool community gardens: Quartz Documentation (this site!) Jacky Zhao‚Äôs Garden Socratica Toolbox oldwinter „ÅÆÊï∞Â≠óËä±Âõ≠ Aaron Pham‚Äôs Garden The Quantum Garden Abhijeet‚Äôs Math Wiki Matt Dunn‚Äôs Second Brain Pelayo Arbues‚Äô Notes Vince Imbat‚Äôs Talahardin üß†üå≥ Chad‚Äôs Mind Garden Pedro MC Fernandes‚Äôs Topo da Mente Mau Camargo‚Äôs Notkesto Caicai‚Äôs Novels üåä Collapsed Wave Sideny‚Äôs 3D Artist‚Äôs Handbook Mike‚Äôs AI Garden ü§ñü™¥ Brandon Boswell‚Äôs Garden Scaling Synthesis - A hypertext research notebook Data Dictionary üß† sspaeti.

item.title: Philosophy of Quartz
item.description: A garden should be a true hypertext The garden is the web as topology. Every walk through the garden creates new paths, new meanings, and when we add things to the garden we add them in a way that allows many future, unpredicted relationships.

item.title: Setting up your GitHub repository
item.description: First, make sure you have Quartz cloned and setup locally. Then, create a new repository on GitHub.com. Do not initialize the new repository with README, license, or gitignore files.

item.title: Migrating from Quartz 3
item.description: As you already have Quartz locally, you don‚Äôt need to fork or clone it again. Simply just checkout the alpha branch, install the dependencies, and import your old vault.

item.title: Layout
item.description: Certain emitters may also output HTML files. To enable easy customization, these emitters allow you to fully rearrange the layout of the page. The default page layouts can be found in quartz.

item.title: Welcome to Quartz 4
item.description: Quartz is a fast, batteries-included static-site generator that transforms Markdown content into fully functional websites. Thousands of students, developers, and teachers are already using Quartz to publish personal notes, websites, and digital gardens to the web.

item.title: Hosting
item.description: Quartz effectively turns your Markdown files and other resources into a bundle of HTML, JS, and CSS files (a website!). However, if you‚Äôd like to publish your site to the world, you need a way to host it online.

item.title: Wikilinks
item.description: Wikilinks were pioneered by earlier internet wikis to make it easier to write links across pages without needing to write Markdown or HTML links each time.
